bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Howard A. Kelly, August 16, 1906

div1.p: Kean argues that Carroll deserves more recognition for his service. The last page includes Kelly's reply, dated September 10, 1906. Kelly writes that he will help to secure cooperation of Congressmen and write an article in support of Congressional action on behalf of the survivors and their families.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Howard A. Kelly, August 16, 1906
div1.p:
WAR DEPARTMENT,
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL,
WASHINGTON.
August 16, 1906. My dear Dr. Kelly:

I was very glad to get your letter of July 25th, and note with special in-
terest what you have to say about Dr. Carroll. I know that he feels that he has not
gotten the reward which should have come to him for his work in Cuba, and in this I
entirely agree with him, and I am very glad to know that you are taking an interest
in the matter. There were difficulties in the way of his getting promotion in 1902
when Gorgas got his and Reed would have gotten his but for his untimely death. These
difficulties Carroll does not, I think, appreciate, but the Surgeon General stands
ready to help him when a suitable opportunity presents itself. I believe that such
opportunity has presented itself this morning and that you are responsible for it.

There was a review of your book in the Outlook for August 11th which, while
it was a little mixed scientifically between malaria and yellow fever, was strongly
written and entirely to the point as regards the rewards which should come to the men
who did this work. It is called “The Republic's Forgetfulness”. The Secretary of
the President has written to say that the President desired a report from the Surgeon
General on the subject, and the Surgeon General has directed me to draw it up, so that
I hope next winter we can do something for Carroll.

The main thing about the passage of these private bills is to have one man
in each House who is sincerely interested. You must, in your large professional and
personal contact with men, meet a number of Congressmen. If you can get some of them
interested in this matter, you will immensely facilitate the passage of this bill.

I think that the Surgeon General will recommend that Carroll be made a major,
and that Congress be asked to appropriate the money for a statue for Reed.
-2-
If Congress erects a statue, as they should, this will leave The Walter Reed Memorial
free to establish a scholarship or do something else in perpetuation of his memory.
I think that your book is going to be a powerful stimulus to the completion of the
Memorial Fund. I am exceedingly anxious to see it completed because I am in a po-
sition to know that Mrs. Reed needs the interest on the fund in order to enable her
to hold on to her little place, which was the strongest of Reed's local attachments,
and every foot of which is associated with him.

Very sincerely yours,
J. R. Kean-

Howard A. Kelly, M. D.,
Indian Point, Parry Sound District
via Brooks Falls,
Ontario, Canada.
Sept. 10, 1906. Dear Major Kean,--

I trust matters are moving
along in Carroll's interest. I will take
active steps to secure the friendly co-
operation of a representative and a member
of the Senate, when you tell me the bill
needs farthering, on my return from Aberdeen.
I am going over to represent the Johns Hopkins
University at the four hundredth anniversary
celebration. I am glad the President is taking
the matter up. I hear on all sides of renewed
interest in the fund, and cannot think that
it will be long before it is completed. A good
many people have written to me, others to
Pres. Gilman, and a number curiously enough
to the McClures, to know to whom to send
a subscription.

The Outlook review was a very kind one,
was it not?

I am going to try to write a popular
article on the subject for one of the Magazines,
on my way over.
I shall be back by Oct. 15th
